Situation1: Their partner faces a tough decision at work and seeks advice and encouragement.
Situation2: They see a group of teenagers ignoring the no-diving signs near the pool edge.
Story: I sat beside my wife on the couch, her hands twisting nervously in her lap. She’d just told me about the promotion offer at work, the one that would mean longer hours and more responsibility. She looked at me, eyes searching for reassurance, for the kind of support she’d always counted on. I reached for her hand, ready to listen, to help her sort through her worries. But through the window, I caught sight of the pool. A group of teenagers was gathering at the deep end, laughing, edging dangerously close to the no-diving signs. My heart thudded. As a lifeguard, I knew I had to act—enforce the rules, keep everyone safe. But my wife’s voice trembled, pulling me back. She needed me, right now, to be her partner, her confidant. I felt torn, the weight of both roles pressing down on me, each demanding my full attention. My mind raced, caught between the urgent call of duty outside and the quiet plea for support beside me.
